title: Three goals in difficult afternoon at Goodison Park | Everton 3-0 AFC Bournemouth
comments:
Could the club arrange training matches Vs 1st team or strong representation from Portsmouth FC Swindon Town FC EastleighFC  Weymouth FC  PooleTown FC Bashley FC & Christchurch FC - so the players receive competition in local pride & rivalry , score more than once in a match & hopefully eventually achieve victory by 3 goals or more ? The psychological effect of winning may help the lads’ mentality a huge deal. 
     My having supported the club since 1973 cannot deny the gratification of ‘Boscombe ‘ giving us top flight football - something I & most never believed we’d see - which makes the current situation worse knowing this position could be lost by those whom weren’t part of the overall or original achievement & a potential loss of footballing status comparable to neighbours Portsmouth or Yeovil Town wouldn’t be suffered by current playing & management personnel but by those faithful within the club machinery ,the replacement players ,those in the stands , the wider community & beyond. 
  Not all the clubs in this league are superclubs & the majority of the players faced by these Cherries aren’t immortals - they’re the same as them , very very good footballers - playing at the summit of English League football & these first pick Cherries all have the potential to be superheroes instead of well paid disappointments every time they pull on the AFC Bournemouth shirt😁👍

So you want Szoboszlai, seeing the dangling leg, to actually fall into it naturally before going to ground and potentially injure himself in the process? Or does he avoid maximizing the contact and simply move to avoid the dangling leg? The leg should not have been dangling. It's clumsy and defenders know not to dangle legs like that in the box, almost guaranteed pen every time.

You do not understand the basics.  "Simulation" means something very specific: it is reacting to non-existent contact.  What Szobo did is called "going down soft", leaving his feet when he could have stayed up if he really wanted to.  Going down soft has never been illegal.  In fact, not only do referees generally have a problem with going down soft, top level referees have been known to actually tell players they need to go down to get the whistle. 

The real question you should ask yourself is whether you prefer players who decided to go down soft before contact, or players who decide after.  IMNSHO, the real cheaters are the ones who are swerving into defenders and are just dropping to the ground at the slightest touch.  Szobo here feels significant contact and then decides to go down.  The referee was not fooled by what Szobo did here, not even a little.

​ @Fractalchemystical his feet is pointing towards goal when the defender's feet is just planted next to his right foot. However, he had the whole time to turn away and fall with both feets flying. Look clearly and tell me his foot was caught in a position where it had no room to move and moving it will cause an injury? Why not just fall onto his right side or fall backwards? He chose to "dive or in ur words lean forward"... The defender in no ways motioned towards him after his leg is planted.

Go support a another team then, if that's what you want to watch. Uni Eropa

Pada 12 Desember 2013, Parlemen Eropa mengeluarkan resolusi yang “mengungkapkan keprihatinan mendalam atas laporan yang terus-menerus dan kredibel mengenai pengambilan organ secara sistematis dan disetujui negara dari tahanan hati nurani yang tidak memberikan persetujuan di Republik Rakyat Tiongkok, termasuk dari sejumlah besar tahanan hati nurani yang ditahan di Republik Rakyat Tiongkok, praktisi Falun Gong yang dipenjara karena keyakinan mereka, serta dari anggota kelompok agama dan etnis minoritas lainnya.” Resolusi tersebut meminta PKT untuk segera membebaskan semua tahanan hati nurani. Direkomendasikan juga agar dilakukan penyelidikan yang menyeluruh dan transparan terhadap perilaku tidak bermoral tersebut.

Konvensi Menentang Perdagangan Organ Tubuh Manusia juga diadopsi oleh Komite Menteri Eropa pada 9 Juli 2014. Konvensi ini melarang perdagangan organ ilegal transnasional dan meminta negara-negara anggotanya untuk menghentikan kejahatan tersebut.

Konvensi ini berlaku di lima negara pertama yang sejauh ini telah meratifikasinya: Albania, Republik Ceko, Malta, Republik Moldova, dan Norwegia pada 1 Maret 2018. 17 negara lainnya juga menandatangani konvensi tersebut, termasuk Belgia, Yunani, Italia, Irlandia, dan Latvia.

Pada April 2019, Belgia mengesahkan undang-undang baru yang mengkriminalisasi semua aktivitas yang terlibat dalam pembelian dan penjualan organ manusia untuk penggunaan komersial.

Y si anota es buen delantero, sería mejor dicho goleador o caza goles. Si bien se ganan partidos con goles. El va llegando al equipo se debe de adaptar y asistirlo con buenos pases para que pueda anotar y también buscar el balónby anotar. ) The Spotsylvania County of Virginia passed a resolution on March 23, 2021, condemning the Chinese Communist Party’s persecution of Falun Gong as well as the brutal crime of harvesting organs from living practitioners.

Since last year, seven other counties in the state have passed similar resolutions to condemn the CCP’s human rights abuses, including Fairfax County, Shenandoah County, Frederick County, Prince William County, Loudoun County, Fauquier County and Warren County.


Board of Supervisors’ Meeting in Spotsylvania County on March 23, 2021

Ms. Wang Chunyan, a Falun Gong practitioner and survivor of torture in China, testified at the Board of Supervisors’ meeting. Ms. Wang said, “I am very honored to stand here today. It also makes me emotional. I was almost killed and could have been made a victim of the organ harvesting crime in China for practicing Falun Gong.”

Ms. Wang was an entrepreneur in Dalian City, Liaoning Province. She was once imprisoned for seven years for upholding her faith and suffered all kinds of brutal torture. When she was forced to live away from home to hide from the police, the police beat her husband to death. Her two sisters were also arrested for talking to people about Falun Gong.

Kevin Marshall, Chairman of Spotsylvania County Board of Supervisors, said, “We don’t want anything like this to go unnoticed.” He said he hopes every resident in the county will be aware of the crime and no one will participate in it.

Moyes would be the manager to fix the problems but there has been a portion of the fans who were only ever waiting for him to have problems and the basically use that as an excuse to whine and whine and whine... So sick of the fabricated despair, when any team or manager will face issues with part of the team not working. This season was until 2024 a huge improvement on last year. But defence has let us down in 2024. 

There were problems in attack and the club's resources went to fixing that and arguably Moyes achieved it, with a very exciting attacking lineup. Meanwhile, the defensive reinforcements haven't worked out and now that Zouma and Ogbonna are over the hill and should not be starting games, there just isn't anyone good enough to replace them. Both Aguerd and Mavraponos can be accident prone. And defence has been a problem now for two seasons. 

Moyes would fix it. He knows how and he most certainly would in the summer if given time and a budget. 

But of course some fans don't want to give him to fix that problem. They are happy that it exists so they can hound him out. They couldn't wait and even when it was just one or two bad games they already started with their abuse and hounding, generating so much negativity that it has slowly seeped into the majority like a poison.

Wait, I thiught West Ham were massive, what happened?

To preface this, I am a Chelsea fan - so any West Ham supporters feel free to tell me if I'm way off here.

It felt like half of the players here didn't know what they were doing tactically. Soucek was consistently caught out of position because he was being tasked with covering the entirety of midfield when Bowen wouldn't track back fast enough and Alvarez was stuck on the right side.
The entirety of the defense felt like they were in two minds about stretching to cover wide runs by Cucurella and Madueke or squeeze in to force them to cross, so they kind of did neither very well and allowed passes to slip in the half spaces between players
It really just felt like, tactically speaking, the team was set up to lose. There was no mind given to how Chelsea had set up against Spurs, so Cucurella was allowed to perform exactly the same free role he did in that game, completely overloading the midfield in possession.

I really don't think the players were to blame in a vacuum, the tactics just felt like they weren't thought through at all.

I would say three things...

1) I would like to see the front four eventually be more flexible and fluid in terms of covering each other defensively. 

2) I would also consider swapping Paqueta and Kudus's positions. I feel that there is a huge requirement for the 10 in that system to support Antonio's press, and we may upset the opposition's build-up more with Kudus taking that role rather than Paqueta. You also gain the link-up between Emerson and Paqueta down the left-hand side that we have seen so frequently this season. This is a consideration rather than an out-and-out suggestion.

3) I agreed with the decision to make a defensive sub at the 65-minute mark, but my sub at the time would have been Phillips for Antonio, go 4-5-1, push Paqueta to the left, and rather than leave Bowen up top, I would have opted for Kudus to be the makeshift CF. 

All in all, it's a relatively new system and there may be tweaks that incrementally improve us. I would have liked this 11 to start the season as soon as Kudus arrived.

It's been excellent so far. We look like we are overwhelming teams at times which is great to see. I still think there is a place for that 'low-block' system that Moyes has employed so frequently this season, but I would like it to be used in 20% of the games, rather than 80%. 

Just my takes from the game.

We are looking like a really, really good side again. If we can continue in the same vein and overwhelm certain teams and revert back to the system we used more frequently at the beginning of the season against certain sides, I think it gives us two ways of getting results.

West Ham United delivered a spectacular performance in the UEFA Europa League, thrashing SC Freiburg with a 5-0 victory. 

Mohammed Kudus’ Wonder Goal: Kudus capped off the night with a sublime solo goal, showcasing his skill and flair. His left-footed shot from outside the box left fans in awe. This goal was the icing on the cake for West Ham’s dominant display.
Lucas Paqueta and Jarrod Bowen: Paqueta and Bowen played pivotal roles, overturning the 1-0 first-leg deficit. Their goals in the first half set the tone for West Ham’s historic win.
Europa League Quarter-Finals: With this emphatic victory, West Ham secured their place in the quarter-finals of the Europa League. It’s a remarkable achievement for the club, marking their third successive appearance in this stage of the competition.
The electric atmosphere at the London Stadium fueled the Hammers’ performance, and they now march forward with confidence. Congratulations to West Ham on this historic night! ⚒🔥

When we scored that first goal early, I was hoping we'd go on to win comfortably 3 or 4-0 but then Paqueta got injured and that was the end of that dream! 
As soon as he goes off, we lose all creativity, spark, vision, everything!

@philwill0123  lol - you're making stuff up. Souček played deeper because initially Moyes wanted Paqueta to play further forward. That was the main failed experiment of early part of last season and mainly because Paqueta couldn't handle the physicality and he was getting brushed off the ball. Souček just had a bad season, nothing to do with tactics. And Rice has had a clear role for years, hasn't changed. Only difference was that Moyes encouraged him to drive forward more and get closer to the box, meaning Souček had to cover more for him when that happened. Souček was struggling more in the box because defenders had got wise to him arriving late and attacking the ball. 

Nothing happens in a vacuum - opposition teams do research on our strengths and try to nullify them. Then you have to add more to the tactics but that also means adding more to the players' game, and that isn't always easy. It's one reason new players can inject new momentum to a team.

Attractive??? Just negative football dude😂😂😂

@muhammadfurqan7952  Negative? Hahahaha - it was the perfect counter-attacking team... soak up the pressure, wait for a mistake and pounce. There is nothing negative about that. It takes huge resilience, concentration and skill, especially in the transition... 

You can only use what you have. There are teams like Brighton that are set up to hold possession and move the ball, but usually those teams struggle against the really good teams that are as good defensively as they are in attack. Many of the top teams combine both counter-attacking and possession football, because they have the type of top players who can do both. 

Too often, our players lose the ball in positions where top teams hold onto to it and can build a possession based attack. Usually, we are better at this as the season progresses, and I think as Paqueta, Alvarez, WP and Kudus become familiar with each other, we will have better play through the middle. 

The problem I see for us over and over is the inability to deal with the high press... so we end up having to do defend rather than break out or even just thread the ball. The high press creates an overlap, so it's three against two, and in that situation, we have come unstuck so many times. It's like we don't see the press working, or we give the ball to a player who doesn't have space, hasn't created space, or cannot handle the close pressure. At least with Rice, we had some composure in those areas. It's no surprise to me that since Rice left, our possession ratio has gone down. We need Paqueta to be able to use his skills and positioning to be the pivot so that we can handle that high press better. 

It isn't just about the manager saying 'I want us to play defensively'. No manager ever says that. But a manager will say 'if we cannot win the game, let's not lose it', and that is something that West Ham have done so much in my 40+ years of following them. Moyes is the first manager I've seen who actually knows how to properly organise a defence, with the possible exception of Rednapp.
